Award.AbstractNarration:
This award was provided as part of NSFâ€™s Social, Behavioral and Economic Sciences Postdoctoral Research Fellowships (SPRF) program. The goal of the SPRF program is to prepare promising, early career doctoral-level scientists for scientific careers in academia, industry or private sector, and government. SPRF awards involve two years of training under the sponsorship of established scientists and encourage Postdoctoral Fellows to perform independent research. NSF seeks to promote the participation of scientists from all segments of the scientific community, including those from underrepresented groups, in its research programs and activities; the postdoctoral period is considered to be an important level of professional development in attaining this goal. Each Postdoctoral Fellow must address important scientific questions that advance their respective disciplinary fields. Under the sponsorship of Dr. James T. Watson at the University of Arizona, this postdoctoral fellowship award supports an early career scientist examining migration and cultural change. Archaeologists often cite migration as an explanatory factor for observed patterns of cultural change. However, relatively few studies scrutinize the purported relationship between changes in material culture and the biological reality of migration. This project will directly test hypothesized migrations, using a bioarchaeological approach to examine phenotypic variation in human skeletal remains to reconstruct patterns of biological relatedness and likely ancient migration patterns. Additionally, through targeted public outreach at museums and schools serving primarily Latinx communities, as well through collaborative workshops, the project will broaden participation of historically underrepresented groups within archaeology and the social sciences.

This project will evaluate how and to what extent migration and cultural change were linked in the past. To test models of migration based on observed material changes in the archaeological record, the Fellow will collect dental and skeletal phenotypic data from approximately 2500 individuals curated in museums and repositories. Biodistance relationship (R) matrix and finite mixture analyses will allow the Fellow to identify past migrations at multiple scales, including large-scale population replacements, as well as small-scale individual migrants. Results will allow archaeologists and anthropologists working on similar topics to better evaluate how and to what extent migration and cultural change were linked in the past. Moreover, the time-depth provided by archaeological studies of migration provides scientists with a means of contextualizing and better understanding the long-term consequences of on-going migration processes today.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of this project was to examine if and how migration affected processes of social and cultural change in ancient Mexico. Dr. Pacheco-Fores collected and analyzed data on tooth size and shape from archaeological human skeletal remains from sites across ancient Mexico to understand how these individuals and populations were biologically related to each other. Understanding patterns of biological kinship across ancient Mexico allowed her to reconstruct how people moved and migrated within and between these regions in the past.

The project was initially proposed to be more ambitious in scope, reconstructing migration patterns within and between northwestern and central Mexico during the Epiclassic (600-900 CE) and Early Postclassic (900-1200 CE) periods. As originally proposed, Dr. Pacheco-Fores planned to collect data from a total of 2,239 individuals from 45 different sites across northern, western, and central Mexico. However, as the global COVID-19 pandemic made domestic and international travel to Mexico impossible, Dr. Pacheco-Fores shifted the emphasis of the project from extensive data collection to analyzing previously collected dental data focusing on central Mexico.

In the five months Dr. Pacheco-Fores was on tenure as an NSF Social, Behavioral and Economic Sciences Postdoctoral Research Fellow (August-December 2020), she used previously collected data on tooth size from a total of 333 individuals from 10 sites across central, northern, and southern Mexico to examine patterns of migration into central Mexico during the Epiclassic period. The Epiclassic period was a time of dramatic social and political upheaval and reorganization following the decline of the regional center of Teotihuacan. It is a period that is often characterized by increased migration into the region, increased competition for resources and economic influence, and increased violence. The central Mexican Epiclassic was therefore a perfect case study in which to examine the relationship between migration and process of social and cultural change.

Results from Dr. Pacheco-Fores? analysis supported previous archaeological theories (primarily based on data from artefacts including ceramics and obsidian) that migrants to central Mexico during this time period came from northwestern Mexico. However, the analysis also suggested Epiclassic migrants into central Mexico may have originated in the Oaxaca Valley in southern Mexico. While there is extensive evidence of Oaxacan migrants coming to central Mexico during the Classic (200-600 CE) period, the Oaxaca Valley had not previously been considered as a possible source region for Epiclassic migrants. These results are exciting, as they suggest that Classic period Oaxacan migration and diaspora networks within central Mexico persisted following the collapse of Teotihuacan and the resultant dramatic regional socio-political reorganizations of the Epiclassic period.

In addition to performing this analysis during the five-month tenure of her fellowship, Dr. Pacheco-Fores also engaged in public outreach activities focused on encouraging greater diversity within the social sciences. Using the Skype A Scientist platform, the Dr. Pacheco-Fores connected digitally with various elementary and middle school classrooms throughout the United States. During these digital sessions, Dr. Pacheco-Fores talked about her path to becoming a bioarchaeologist (an archaeologist who specializes in the analysis of human skeletal remains from archaeological contexts), as well as how these techniques allow scientists to learn about the past. These sessions were conducted in English and in Spanish, depending on whether the students were enrolled at a traditional or Spanish-immersion school. Through the course of bilingual presentations to elementary and middle school students--especially those conducted in Spanish with Spanish-speaking students?Dr. Pacheco-Fores was able to encourage and nurture a broad interest in science and in archaeology and bioarchaeology specifically among students of Latin American descent. After these presentations, the class teachers often sent thank you notes from the students where they expressed a greater interest in science, wonder at what archaeologists and bioarchaeologists can learn about the past, and general excitement about continuing to study science.

Finally, during Dr. Pacheco-Fores? tenure as an NSF postdoctoral fellow, she published an open-access article examining migration and violence in Epiclassic central Mexico in the Journal of Anthropological Archaeology. She began writing a manuscript relating the results of her analysis of the origins of central Mexican migrant populations completed during the fellowship period, and she submitted a presentation abstract on this research that was accepted and ultimately presented at the American Association of Physical Anthropologists? 90th annual meeting, which occurred virtually in March 2021.

Dr. Pacheco-Fores terminated the fellowship early (December 2020) because she earned a tenure-track assistant professor position at Hamline University in Saint Paul, Minnesota with a start date of January 2021. Thus, while she was not able to complete the project as originally proposed, due to both the global COVID-19 pandemic and the premature termination of the fellowship, she still accomplished several key goals of the proposed project, including investigating migration and its relationship to social change in ancient Mexico and encouraging greater diversity in the social sciences through targeted outreach activities.
